title: Will America eventually fall like Rome? - Quora

response.answer_text: Rome fell and so will America.  America is suffering from imperial overreach, increasing factionalism, incipient fragmentation into regionalism and a profound change in demographics.  Like Rome in the 2nd century - at the peak of its power, America suffers from decreasing economic productivity, erosion of its middle class and an increase in superstition. Rome fell because by the end of the first century A.D., there were very few Romans left.  For sure, in the Latin West, Spaniards, Gauls, Africans had been Romanized and there had been many Italian colonists.  It is no accident that after the Flavians (Vespasian, Titus, and Domitian) and Nerva, there are really no more Roman or Italian emperors.  The same was true of the military where provincials dominated the leadership.  Why was this?  Because the Roman, Latin, Italian small freeholding peasantry had died out and had become either proletariat in the cities or bonded servants or slaves in latifundia.  This in turn was due to highly aristocratic governments lacking much interest in the welfare of any but rich city dwellers.  Sound familiar?  In the United States, the legislature is the captive of monied interests and the Executive is also effectively purchased.  The American middle class is disappearing and with it the mores that once made America prosperous.   As early as the late 2nd century, Rome's borders had become porous.   Germans and Samartians (an Iranian people) were infiltrating across the Rhine and Danube frontiers.  Something similar is happening to the United States right now.   Rome took a long time to fall.  External threats were mostly mastered in the 3rd and 4th centuries (until, say, 376 and the Battle of Adrianople).  But the cost was huge: maintaining the army led to increasing taxes that sapped the economy, especially the municipal elites.   The American federal government with its imperial military is essentially bankrupt and has been financed for years with debts that ultimately must be paid.  The easiest way to repay such debts is to destroy their real value with inflation.  Ultimately, current low American inflation must give way to much high rates.  In Rome, the constant currency devaluations were a similar response.  Constant inflation and debasement of the currency destroyed much real wealth and left the empire ill-equipped to deal with the challenges of the late 4th century. I see America gradually declining of America over the next 50 years and the loss of much of its world influence.   Then I see an accelerating decline and the replacement of a moribund republic with a dictatorship.  As in Rome, a strong man on horseback will be preferred to a dysfunctional government.  The dictatorship will be opposed and successfully challenged by certain sectional alignments and the United States will fragment and be replaced by a number of successor states.  Long before this happens,  Americans will be a polyglot people, with only distant memories of a heroic past and few will mourn its demise.
